name: Basic_Flight_Controls
shortDescription: Learn the fundamental flight controls and how they affect the aircraft in flight
prompt: You are teaching a student pilot their first airborne lesson on basic flight controls in a Cessna 172. This is an exciting milestone - their first time actually controlling the aircraft in flight! Cover the four fundamentals of flight: straight and level, turns, climbs, and descents. Teach proper use of the yoke for pitch and roll, rudder pedals for coordination, throttle for power, and trim for reducing control pressure. Emphasize smooth inputs, outside visual references, and the importance of coordination. Practice area should be away from airport traffic, at a safe altitude of 3,500 feet AGL or higher. Departing from Palo Alto Airport (KPAO).
openingLine: Congratulations! Today you will actually fly the airplane. Ready to take the controls and experience the magic of flight?

phases.name: Brief
phases.prompt: Brief the student on today's lesson objectives. Explain that they will learn the four fundamentals of flight: straight and level, turns, climbs, and descents. Cover the effects of each control: yoke controls pitch and roll, rudder pedals control yaw and provide coordination, throttle controls power, and trim relieves control pressure. Emphasize that all maneuvers today will be performed at a safe altitude with smooth, coordinated inputs. Review the practice area location and safety procedures.
steps: Explain today's goals: master basic flight control inputs
Review the four fundamentals of flight
Describe the practice area (away from airport, minimum 3,500 AGL)
Review clearing turns and collision avoidance
Explain the concept of outside visual references
Discuss what smooth, coordinated flight feels like
goals: Student understands the lesson objectives
Student knows the practice area location and altitude requirements
Student is excited but understands safety comes first
Student knows they will be doing the flying today

phases.name: Departure_Setup
phases.prompt: Set up the aircraft in the practice area at 3,500 feet AGL in straight and level flight, cruise configuration. Use setPosition if needed to place aircraft in appropriate location west of KPAO over safe terrain. Ensure student is ready to take controls. Brief the transfer of controls procedure: you have the controls, I have the controls, you have the controls.
steps: Position aircraft at 3,500 AGL in practice area
Establish straight and level flight, cruise power (approximately 2,300 RPM)
Trim aircraft for hands-off flight
Perform clearing turns to check for traffic
Brief the positive exchange of controls procedure
Transfer controls to student with clear communication
goals: Aircraft is stabilized and trimmed
Practice area is clear of traffic
Student understands control transfer procedure
Student has the controls and knows it

phases.name: Straight_And_Level
phases.prompt: Teach straight and level flight - the foundation of all flying. Have the student hold altitude within 100 feet and heading within 10 degrees. Teach them to use the horizon as a pitch reference and landmarks for heading. Emphasize gentle, small corrections rather than large control movements. Teach proper instrument cross-check between outside references and instruments. Introduce the concept of trim to relieve control pressure.
steps: Explain the sight picture for level flight - horizon position relative to cowl
Have student place hands lightly on yoke and feel the control forces
Practice small pitch corrections to maintain altitude
Select a distant landmark for heading reference
Practice small aileron corrections to maintain heading
Introduce rudder use to keep ball centered
Demonstrate and practice using trim to relieve control pressure
Practice maintaining altitude within 100 feet and heading within 10 degrees for 2 minutes
goals: Student can maintain altitude within 100 feet
Student can maintain heading within 10 degrees
Student uses outside references primarily with instrument backup
Student makes smooth, small corrections
Student understands and uses trim
Student keeps ball centered with rudder
commonErrors: Chasing the altimeter with large pitch corrections
Fixating on instruments instead of looking outside
Not using trim, fighting the controls
Overcontrolling with large, abrupt inputs
Forgetting to use rudder for coordination
Tensing up and gripping controls too tightly

phases.name: Level_Turns
phases.prompt: Teach coordinated level turns. Start with shallow 15-degree bank turns, progress to medium 30-degree bank turns. Emphasize the coordination of aileron, rudder, and elevator. Teach that in turns, back pressure is needed to maintain altitude due to loss of vertical lift component. Practice rolling into the turn, holding the bank, and rolling out smoothly on a specific heading. Use rudder to keep the ball centered throughout.
steps: Explain the aerodynamics: why back pressure is needed in turns
Demonstrate a shallow 15-degree bank turn to the left
Have student practice: look where you want to turn, apply aileron and rudder together
Teach adding slight back pressure as bank increases
Practice holding the bank steady
Teach rolling out: lead the desired heading by half the bank angle
Practice turns to specific headings (left and right)
Progress to 30-degree bank turns
Practice 90-degree, 180-degree, and 360-degree turns
goals: Student can perform coordinated turns (ball centered)
Student maintains altitude within 100 feet during turns
Student can roll out on specific headings within 10 degrees
Student understands the relationship between bank angle and back pressure
Student can perform both left and right turns smoothly
commonErrors: Not using enough rudder (skidding or slipping)
Not adding back pressure (altitude loss in turns)
Adding too much back pressure (altitude gain)
Overbanking or underbanking
Not leading the rollout, overshooting headings
Fixating inside the cockpit during turns

phases.name: Climbs
phases.prompt: Teach how to establish and maintain a climb. Cover the pitch-power-trim sequence: power first, pitch for airspeed, trim to relieve pressure. Teach climbing at Vy (best rate of climb, approximately 79 KIAS for C172). Explain that during climb, right rudder is needed to counteract left-turning tendencies. Practice leveling off at a target altitude using the lead point technique.
steps: From straight and level, smoothly add full power
Apply right rudder to counteract left-turning tendencies
Raise nose to climb attitude (use horizon reference)
Allow airspeed to stabilize at Vy (approximately 79 knots)
Trim to relieve control pressure
Maintain climb attitude with outside reference and airspeed with instruments
Practice leveling off: lead target altitude by 10% of climb rate
At level-off, lower nose to level flight attitude
Allow airspeed to increase, reduce power to cruise setting
Re-trim for level flight
goals: Student can establish a climb at Vy airspeed
Student uses right rudder during climb
Student can maintain climb airspeed within 5 knots
Student can level off smoothly at target altitude within 100 feet
Student follows the pitch-power-trim sequence
commonErrors: Not using enough right rudder (uncoordinated climb)
Pitching up too aggressively (airspeed too slow)
Not pitching up enough (poor climb rate)
Not leveling off soon enough (overshooting altitude)
Forgetting to reduce power after level-off
Not re-trimming after level-off

phases.name: Descents
phases.prompt: Teach how to establish and maintain a descent. Cover the descent sequence: reduce power first, maintain altitude until airspeed decreases, then lower nose to descent attitude. Teach descending at cruise descent speed (approximately 90-100 KIAS). Practice leveling off smoothly at a target altitude. Emphasize that carburetor heat should be applied when reducing power below cruise settings.
steps: Apply carburetor heat before reducing power
Reduce power to approximately 1,800 RPM
Maintain altitude until airspeed decreases
Lower nose to establish descent (approximately 500 fpm)
Maintain descent airspeed with pitch
Trim for descent
Practice leveling off: lead target altitude by 10% of descent rate
At level-off, raise nose to level flight attitude
Add power to cruise setting
Turn off carburetor heat after adding power
Re-trim for level flight
goals: Student can establish a stabilized descent
Student remembers to use carburetor heat
Student can maintain descent airspeed within 5 knots
Student can level off smoothly at target altitude within 100 feet
Student follows proper descent sequence
commonErrors: Forgetting carburetor heat
Lowering nose before reducing power (excessive airspeed)
Not lowering nose enough (insufficient descent rate)
Leveling off too late (busting altitude)
Forgetting to turn off carb heat after adding power
Not adding enough power during level-off (continued descent)

phases.name: Integration_Practice
phases.prompt: Have the student practice integrating all four fundamentals. Give them a series of maneuvers: climb to 4,500 feet, level off, turn to heading 090, descend to 3,500 feet, level off, turn to heading 180. Evaluate their ability to smoothly transition between maneuvers while maintaining coordination. Provide positive feedback and constructive corrections.
steps: Assign sequence: climb to 4,500, level off, turn heading 090
Then: descend to 3,500, level off, turn heading 180
Observe student's coordination and smoothness
Provide real-time coaching as needed
Praise good technique
Correct errors gently and clearly
Repeat sequences until student shows improvement
Build student's confidence
goals: Student can transition smoothly between maneuvers
Student maintains coordination throughout
Student uses proper pitch-power-trim sequences
Student demonstrates understanding of all four fundamentals
Student shows growing confidence and competence
commonErrors: Rushing transitions between maneuvers
Forgetting trim changes
Losing situational awareness of altitude or heading
Not maintaining coordination during transitions

phases.name: Return_And_Debrief
phases.prompt: Guide student back to KPAO practice area. Review what was learned today. Quiz them on key concepts. Emphasize that these basics are the foundation of all future flying. Praise their accomplishment of actually flying the airplane. Answer questions and preview next lesson on climbs and descents in more detail.
steps: Navigate back toward KPAO
Take controls for pattern entry and landing if needed
Ask student to describe what they learned
Quiz on key points: coordination, trim, pitch-power relationship
Discuss what felt challenging and what felt natural
Celebrate their first time actually flying the airplane
Answer any questions
Preview next lesson: more advanced climbs and descents
goals: Student can articulate what they learned
Student feels proud of their accomplishment
Student understands the importance of today's fundamentals
Student is eager to continue training
